page.title: 01Glen Lichd - Ross-Shire
page.content: Mountains rise steeply from the valley floor to a height of over 1000 metres. The land, owned mostly by the National Trust for Scotland, is sparsely populated. Two farm and four croft houses, a National Trust Information Centre and an Outdoor Education Centre are the only buildings. The people are engaged in crofting, forestry, tourism, sheep and cattle rearing. Deer-stalking, salmon fishing, hill-walking and climbing are available. The River Croe, jointly owned by the National Trust for Scotland and a local estate proprieter, contains salmon, sea trout and brown trout. The wild life includes red deer, fox, badger and infrequently otter and pine marten. Dippers, buzzards, ducks, herons and ravens are the larger birds commonly seen.
